Accessing the Bounds of the Attributed String

inlineContent.text: Attributed strings

are character strings that have attributes for individual characters or ranges of characters. Attributes provide traits like visual styles for display, accessibility for guided access, and hyperlink data for linking between data sources. Attribute keys provide the name and value type of each attribute. System frameworks like Foundation and SwiftUI define common keys, and you can define your own in custom extensions.

Attributed strings store their attributes in attribute containers, and provide key path-based access by implementing dynamic member lookup. As a result, you can access an attribute by name with Swift’s dot syntax. For example, the following code sets the
attribute to the value
, which a UI toolkit like SwiftUI can then render as bold text.

code: var attributedString = AttributedString("This is a basic string.")

inlineContent.text: Attributes can also apply to only part of an attributed string, by applying the attribute to a range.

code: var attributedString = AttributedString("This is a basic string that contains a link.")

inlineContent.text: You can access portions of the string with unique combinations of attributes by iterating over the string’s
property.
You can create an attributed string by passing a standard
or
instance that contains the Markdown syntax to initializers like
. The attributed string creates attributes according to the markup in the string.
Localized strings that you load from strings files with initializers like
can also contain Markdown to add styling attributes. In addition, these localized attributed string initializers can apply the

attribute, which allows you to determine the range of replacement strings, whose order may vary between languages. Localized attributed strings can also use the Markdown extension syntax to indicate parts of the string where the system can apply the automatic grammar agreement feature.
The
API defines keys for common uses, such as text styling, semantically marking up formattable types like dates and numbers, and hyperlinking. You can find these in the
enumeration, which contains attributes for Foundation, SwiftUI, UIKit, and AppKit.
You can define your own attributes by implementing
, and reference them by name by collecting them in an
